The **Hollywood Walk of Fame** comprises more than 2,600[1] five-pointed
[terrazzo](/wiki/Terrazzo "Terrazzo") and [brass](/wiki/Brass "Brass") stars
embedded in the [sidewalks](/wiki/Sidewalk "Sidewalk") along 15
[blocks](/wiki/City_block "City block") of [Hollywood
Boulevard](/wiki/Hollywood_Boulevard "Hollywood Boulevard") and three blocks
of [Vine Street](/wiki/Vine_Street "Vine Street") in
[Hollywood](/wiki/Hollywood "Hollywood"), [California](/wiki/California
"California"). The stars are permanent public monuments to achievement in the
[entertainment industry](/wiki/Entertainment_industry "Entertainment
industry"), bearing the names of a mix of actors, musicians, directors,
producers, musical and theatrical groups, fictional characters, and others.
The Walk of Fame is administered by the Hollywood [Chamber of
Commerce](/wiki/Chamber_of_commerce "Chamber of commerce") and maintained by
the self-financing Hollywood Historic Trust. It is a popular tourist
destination, with a reported 10 million visitors in 2003.[2]

##
Description[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Description")]

The Walk of Fame runs 1.3 miles (2.1 km) east to west on Hollywood Boulevard
from Gower Street to [La Brea Avenue](/wiki/La_Brea_Avenue "La Brea Avenue"),
plus a short segment of Marshfield Way that runs diagonally between Hollywood
and La Brea; and 0.4 miles (0.64 km) north to south on Vine Street between
Yucca Street and [Sunset Boulevard](/wiki/Sunset_Boulevard "Sunset
Boulevard"). According to a 2003 report by the market research firm NPO Plog
Research, the Walk attracts about 10 million visitors annually—more than
[Sunset Strip](/wiki/Sunset_Strip "Sunset Strip"), [TCL Chinese
Theatre](/wiki/TCL_Chinese_Theatre "TCL Chinese Theatre") (formerly
Grauman's), the _[Queen Mary](/wiki/RMS_Queen_Mary "RMS Queen Mary")_ , and
the [Los Angeles County Museum of Art](/wiki/Los_Angeles_County_Museum_of_Art
"Los Angeles County Museum of Art")—and has played an important role in making
tourism the largest industry in [Los Angeles County](/wiki/Los_Angeles_County
"Los Angeles County").[3]

###
Categorization[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Categorization")]

As of
2018[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit),
the Walk of Fame comprises over 2,600 stars,[1] spaced at 6-foot (1.8 m)
intervals. The monuments are coral-pink [terrazzo](/wiki/Terrazzo "Terrazzo")
five-point stars rimmed with [brass](/wiki/Brass "Brass") (not bronze, an oft-
repeated inaccuracy[4]) inlaid into a charcoal-colored terrazzo background. In
the upper portion of each star field the name of the honoree is inlaid in
brass block letters. Below the inscription, in the lower half of the star
field, a round inlaid brass emblem indicates the category of the honoree's
contributions. The emblems symbolize five categories within the entertainment
industry:

>   * [![Circular 4-inch brass plaque showing a side view of a classic movie
> camera](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Walk_of_Fame_Category_Motion_Pictures.jpg/40px-
> Walk_of_Fame_Category_Motion_Pictures.jpg)](/wiki/File:Walk_of_Fame_Category_Motion_Pictures.jpg)
> _**Classic film camera**_ representing [motion pictures](/wiki/Film "Film")
>   * [![Circular 4-inch brass plaque with a tube-type television with twin
> aerials](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Walk_of_Fame_Category_Television.jpg/40px-
> Walk_of_Fame_Category_Television.jpg)](/wiki/File:Walk_of_Fame_Category_Television.jpg)
> _**Television receiver**_ representing [broadcast
> television](/wiki/Terrestrial_television "Terrestrial television")
>   * [![Circular 4-inch brass plaque with a top view of phonograph disc and
> pickup
> arm](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Walk_of_Fame_Category_Recording.jpg/40px-
> Walk_of_Fame_Category_Recording.jpg)](/wiki/File:Walk_of_Fame_Category_Recording.jpg)
> _**Phonograph record**_ representing [audio
> recording](/wiki/Sound_recording_and_reproduction "Sound recording and
> reproduction") or [music](/wiki/Music "Music")
>   * [![Circular 4-inch brass plaque with an antique studio-style
> microphone](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Walk_of_Fame_Category_Radio.jpg/40px-
> Walk_of_Fame_Category_Radio.jpg)](/wiki/File:Walk_of_Fame_Category_Radio.jpg)
> _**Radio microphone**_ representing [broadcast
> radio](/wiki/Radio_broadcasting "Radio broadcasting")
>   * [![Circular 4-inch brass plaque with the classic theatrical
> comedy/tragedy
> masks](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Walk_of_Fame_Category_Theater.jpg/40px-
> Walk_of_Fame_Category_Theater.jpg)](/wiki/File:Walk_of_Fame_Category_Theater.jpg)
> _**Comedy/tragedy masks**_ representing [theatre](/wiki/Theatre
> "Theatre")/[live performance](/wiki/Play_\(theatre\) "Play \(theatre\)")
> (added in 1984)
>

Of [all the stars on the Walk to
date](/wiki/List_of_stars_on_the_Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame "List of stars on the
Hollywood Walk of Fame"), 47% have been awarded in the motion pictures
category, 24% in television, 17% in audio recording, 10% in radio, and fewer
than 2% in the live performance category. Approximately 20 new stars are added
to the Walk each year.[4]

### Special
stars[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Special stars")]

Special category stars recognize various contributions by corporate entities,
service organizations, and special honorees, and display emblems unique to
those honorees.[5] For example, former Los Angeles mayor [Tom
Bradley](/wiki/Tom_Bradley_\(American_politician\) "Tom Bradley \(American
politician\)")'s star displays the [Seal of the City of Los
Angeles](/wiki/Seal_of_the_City_of_Los_Angeles "Seal of the City of Los
Angeles");[6][7] the [Los Angeles Police
Department](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Police_Department "Los Angeles Police
Department") (LAPD) star emblem is a replica of a Hollywood Division badge;[8]
and stars representing corporations, such as [Victoria's
Secret](/wiki/Victoria%27s_Secret "Victoria's Secret") and the [Los Angeles
Dodgers](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Dodgers "Los Angeles Dodgers"), display the
honoree's corporate logo.[5][9] The "Friends of the Walk of Fame" monuments
are charcoal terrazzo squares rimmed by miniature pink terrazzo stars
displaying the five standard category emblems, along with the sponsor's
corporate logo, with the sponsor's name and contribution in inlaid brass block
lettering.[10][11] Special stars and Friends monuments are granted by the
Hollywood Chamber of Commerce or the Hollywood Historic Trust, but are not
part of the Walk of Fame proper and are located nearby on private
property.[10][12]

The monuments for the [Apollo 11](/wiki/Apollo_11 "Apollo 11") mission to the
Moon are uniquely shaped: Four identical circular moons, bearing the names of
the three [astronauts](/wiki/Astronaut "Astronaut") ([Neil A.
Armstrong](/wiki/Neil_Armstrong "Neil Armstrong"), [Edwin E. Aldrin
Jr.](/wiki/Buzz_Aldrin "Buzz Aldrin"), [Michael
Collins](/wiki/Michael_Collins_\(astronaut\) "Michael Collins \(astronaut\)"))
the date of the [first Moon landing](/wiki/Moon_landing "Moon landing")
("7/20/69"), and the words "Apollo XI", are set on each of the four corners of
the intersection of [Hollywood and Vine](/wiki/Hollywood_and_Vine "Hollywood
and Vine"). The moons are silver and grey terrazzo circles rimmed in brass on
a square pink terrazzo background, with the television emblem inlaid at the
top of each circle.[13]

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: History")]

###
Origin[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Origin")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Hollywood_boulevard_from_kodak_theatre.jpg/220px-
Hollywood_boulevard_from_kodak_theatre.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hollywood_boulevard_from_kodak_theatre.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hollywood_boulevard_from_kodak_theatre.jpg "Enlarge")

The Walk of Fame at the 6800 block of Hollywood Boulevard, looking eastward.
The Dolby Theatre is in the foreground at left. In the upper left quadrant is
the famous intersection of [Hollywood and Highland
Center](/wiki/Hollywood_and_Highland_Center "Hollywood and Highland Center").

The Hollywood Chamber of Commerce credits E.M. Stuart, its volunteer president
in 1953, with the original idea for creating a Walk of Fame. Stuart reportedly
proposed the Walk as a means to "maintain the glory of a community whose name
means glamour and excitement in the four corners of the world."[14] Harry
Sugarman, another Chamber member and president of the Hollywood Improvement
Association, receives credit in an independent account.[15] A committee was
formed to flesh out the idea, and an architectural firm was retained to
develop specific proposals. By 1955 the basic concept and general design had
been agreed upon, and plans were submitted to the [Los Angeles City
Council](/wiki/Los_Angeles_City_Council "Los Angeles City Council").

Multiple accounts exist for the origin of the star concept. According to one,
the historic [Hollywood Hotel](/wiki/Hollywood_Hotel "Hollywood Hotel")—which
stood for more than 50 years on Hollywood Boulevard at the site now occupied
by the [Hollywood and Highland complex](/wiki/Hollywood_and_Highland
"Hollywood and Highland") and the [Dolby (formerly Kodak)
Theatre](/wiki/Dolby_Theatre "Dolby Theatre")[16]—displayed stars on its
dining room ceiling above the tables favored by its most famous celebrity
patrons, and that may have served as an early inspiration.[17] By another
account, the stars were "inspired ... by Sugarman's [Tropics Restaurant]
drinks menu, which featured celebrity photos framed in gold stars."[15][18]

In February 1956 a prototype was unveiled featuring a
[caricature](/wiki/Caricature "Caricature") of an example honoree ([John
Wayne](/wiki/John_Wayne "John Wayne"), by some accounts[19]) inside a blue
star on a brown background.[14] However, caricatures proved too expensive and
difficult to execute in brass with the technology available at the time; and
the brown and blue motif was vetoed by [Charles E.
Toberman](/wiki/Charles_E._Toberman "Charles E. Toberman"), the legendary real
estate developer known as "Mr. Hollywood", because the colors clashed with a
new building he was erecting on Hollywood Boulevard.[14][20]

### Selection and
construction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Selection and construction")]

By March 1956 the final design and coral-and-charcoal color scheme had been
approved, and between the spring of 1956 and the fall of 1957, 1,558 honorees
were selected by committees representing the four major branches of the
entertainment industry at that time: motion pictures, television, audio
recording, and radio. The committees met at the [Brown
Derby](/wiki/Brown_Derby "Brown Derby") restaurant,[21] and included such
prominent names as [Cecil B. DeMille](/wiki/Cecil_B._DeMille "Cecil B.
DeMille"), [Samuel Goldwyn](/wiki/Samuel_Goldwyn "Samuel Goldwyn"), [Jesse L.
Lasky](/wiki/Jesse_L._Lasky "Jesse L. Lasky"), [Walt Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney
"Walt Disney"), [Hal Roach](/wiki/Hal_Roach "Hal Roach"), [Mack
Sennett](/wiki/Mack_Sennett "Mack Sennett"), and [Walter
Lantz](/wiki/Walter_Lantz "Walter Lantz").[14]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3e/Hwof_joanne_woodward.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hwof_joanne_woodward.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hwof_joanne_woodward.jpg "Enlarge")

Woodward's star, contrary to popular belief, was not the first.

A requirement stipulated by the original audio recording committee (and later
rescinded) specified minimum sales of one million records or 250,000 albums
for all music category nominees. The committee soon realized that many
important recording artists would be excluded from the Walk by that
requirement. As a result, the [National Academy of Recording Arts and
Sciences](/wiki/National_Academy_of_Recording_Arts_and_Sciences "National
Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences") was formed for the purpose of
creating a separate award system for the music business. The first [Grammy
Awards](/wiki/Grammy_Award "Grammy Award") were presented in Beverly Hills in
1959.[22]

Construction of the Walk began in 1958 but two lawsuits delayed completion.
The first was filed by local property owners challenging the legality of the
[$](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States dollar")1.25 million tax
assessment levied upon them to pay for the Walk, along with new street
lighting and trees. In October 1959 the assessment was ruled legal.[14] The
second lawsuit, filed by [Charles Chaplin, Jr.](/wiki/Charles_Chaplin,_Jr.
"Charles Chaplin, Jr."), sought damages for the exclusion of his father, whose
nomination had been withdrawn due to pressure from multiple quarters (see
[Controversial additions](/wiki/Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame#Controversial_additions
"Hollywood Walk of Fame")). Chaplin's suit was dismissed in 1960, paving the
way for completion of the project.[14][23][24]

While [Joanne Woodward](/wiki/Joanne_Woodward "Joanne Woodward") is often
singled out as the first to receive a star on the Walk of Fame,[25] in fact
there was no "first" recipient; the original stars were installed as a
continuous project, with no individual ceremonies. Woodward's name was one of
eight drawn at random from the original 1,558 and inscribed on eight prototype
stars that were built while litigation was still holding up permanent
construction.[26][27][28] The eight prototypes were installed temporarily on
the northwest corner of Hollywood Boulevard and [Highland
Avenue](/wiki/Highland_Avenue_\(Los_Angeles\) "Highland Avenue \(Los
Angeles\)") in August 1958 to generate publicity and to demonstrate how the
Walk would eventually look.[14] The other seven names were [Olive
Borden](/wiki/Olive_Borden "Olive Borden"), [Ronald
Colman](/wiki/Ronald_Colman "Ronald Colman"), [Louise
Fazenda](/wiki/Louise_Fazenda "Louise Fazenda"), [Preston
Foster](/wiki/Preston_Foster "Preston Foster"), [Burt
Lancaster](/wiki/Burt_Lancaster "Burt Lancaster"), [Edward
Sedgwick](/wiki/Edward_Sedgwick "Edward Sedgwick"), and [Ernest
Torrence](/wiki/Ernest_Torrence "Ernest Torrence").[14][29] Official
groundbreaking took place on February 8, 1960.[17] On March 28, 1960, the
first permanent star, director [Stanley Kramer](/wiki/Stanley_Kramer "Stanley
Kramer")'s, was completed on the easternmost end of the new Walk near the
intersection of Hollywood and Gower.[14][30] The Joanne Woodward legend may
have originated, according to one source, because she was the first to pose
with her star for photographers.[25]

### Stagnation and
revitalization[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Stagnation and revitalization")]

Though the Walk was originally conceived in part to encourage redevelopment of
Hollywood Boulevard, the 1960s and 1970s were periods of protracted urban
decay in the Hollywood area as residents moved to suburbs.[31][32] After the
initial installation of approximately 1,500 stars in 1960 and 1961, eight
years passed without the addition of a new star. In 1962 the Los Angeles City
Council passed an ordinance naming the Hollywood Chamber of Commerce "the
agent to advise the City" about adding names to the Walk, and the Chamber,
over the following six years, devised rules, procedures, and financing methods
to do so.[14] In December 1968, [Richard D. Zanuck](/wiki/Richard_D._Zanuck
"Richard D. Zanuck") was awarded the first star in eight years in a
presentation ceremony hosted by [Danny Thomas](/wiki/Danny_Thomas "Danny
Thomas").[14][21][33] In July 1978 the [City of Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles
"Los Angeles") designated the Hollywood Walk of Fame a [Los Angeles Historic-
Cultural Monument](/wiki/List_of_Los_Angeles_Historic-
Cultural_Monuments_in_Hollywood "List of Los Angeles Historic-Cultural
Monuments in Hollywood").[34]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Joe_Pasternak_Allan_Warren.jpg/220px-
Joe_Pasternak_Allan_Warren.jpg)](/wiki/File:Joe_Pasternak_Allan_Warren.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Joe_Pasternak_Allan_Warren.jpg "Enlarge")

Johnny Grant, center, at producer [Joe Pasternak](/wiki/Joe_Pasternak "Joe
Pasternak")'s presentation ceremony in 1991. At left is [Gene
Kelly](/wiki/Gene_Kelly "Gene Kelly").

Radio personality, television producer and Chamber member [Johnny
Grant](/wiki/Johnny_Grant_\(radio_personality\) "Johnny Grant \(radio
personality\)") is generally credited with implementing the changes that
resuscitated the Walk and established it as a significant tourist
attraction.[21][35] Beginning in 1968, he stimulated publicity and encouraged
international press coverage by requiring that each recipient personally
attend his or her star's unveiling ceremony.[21] Grant later recalled that "it
was tough to get people to come accept a star" until the neighborhood finally
began its recovery in the 1980s.[32] In 1980 he instituted a fee of $2,500,
payable by the person or entity nominating the recipient, to fund the Walk of
Fame's upkeep and minimize further taxpayer burden.[21] The fee has increased
incrementally over time; by 2002 it had reached $15,000,[36] and stood at
$30,000 in 2012.[4] The current (2017) fee is $40,000.[37]

Grant was awarded a star in 1980 for his television work.[14] In 2002, he
received a second star in the "special" category to acknowledge his pivotal
role in improving and popularizing the Walk.[38] He was also named chairman of
the Selection Committee and Honorary [Mayor of
Hollywood](/wiki/Mayor_of_Hollywood "Mayor of Hollywood") (a ceremonial
position previously held by [Art Linkletter](/wiki/Art_Linkletter "Art
Linkletter") and [Monty Hall](/wiki/Monty_Hall "Monty Hall"),[39][40] among
others).[14][38] He remained in both offices from 1980 until his death in 2008
and hosted the great majority of unveiling ceremonies during that period. His
unique special-category star, with its emblem depicting a stylized "Great Seal
of the City of Hollywood",[41] is located at the entrance to the Dolby Theatre
adjacent to Johnny Grant Way.[42]

###
Expansion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Expansion")]

In 1984 a fifth category, Live Theatre, was added to permit acknowledgment of
contributions from the live performance branch of the entertainment industry,
and a second row of stars was created on each sidewalk to alternate with the
existing stars.[14]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Hollywood-walk-of-
fame.jpg/170px-Hollywood-walk-of-fame.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hollywood-walk-of-
fame.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hollywood-walk-of-fame.jpg "Enlarge")

Hollywood Boulevard, 7000 block, north side, looking westward

In 1994 the Walk of Fame was extended one block to the west on Hollywood
Boulevard, from Sycamore Avenue to North LaBrea Avenue (plus the short segment
of Marshfield Way that connects Hollywood and La Brea), where it now ends at
the silver "Four Ladies of Hollywood" gazebo and the special "Walk of Fame"
star.[43] At the same time, [Sophia Loren](/wiki/Sophia_Loren "Sophia Loren")
was honored with the 2,000th star on the Walk.[14]

During construction of tunnels for the [Los Angeles subway
system](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Metro_Rail "Los Angeles Metro Rail") in 1996, the
[Metropolitan Transportation
Authority](/wiki/Los_Angeles_County_Metropolitan_Transportation_Authority "Los
Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority") removed and stored more
than 300 stars.[44] Controversy arose when the MTA proposed a money-saving
measure of [jackhammering](/wiki/Jackhammer "Jackhammer") the 3-by-3-foot
terrazzo pads, preserving only the brass lettering, surrounds, and medallions,
then pouring new terrazzo after the tunnels were completed;[45] but the
[Cultural Heritage Commission](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Historic-Cultural_Monument
"Los Angeles Historic-Cultural Monument") ruled that the star pads were to be
removed intact.[46]

###
Restoration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Restoration")]

In 2008 a long-term restoration project began with an evaluation of all 2,365
stars on the Walk at the time, each receiving a letter grade of A, B, C, D, or
F. Honorees whose stars received F grades, indicating the most severe damage,
were [Joan Collins](/wiki/Joan_Collins "Joan Collins"), [Peter
Frampton](/wiki/Peter_Frampton "Peter Frampton"), [Dick Van
Patten](/wiki/Dick_Van_Patten "Dick Van Patten"), [Paul
Douglas](/wiki/Paul_Douglas_\(actor\) "Paul Douglas \(actor\)"), [Andrew L.
Stone](/wiki/Andrew_L._Stone "Andrew L. Stone"), [Willard
Waterman](/wiki/Willard_Waterman "Willard Waterman"), [Richard
Boleslavsky](/wiki/Richard_Boleslavsky "Richard Boleslavsky"), [Ellen
Drew](/wiki/Ellen_Drew "Ellen Drew"), [Frank Crumit](/wiki/Frank_Crumit "Frank
Crumit"), and [Bobby Sherwood](/wiki/Bobby_Sherwood "Bobby Sherwood"). Fifty
celebrities' stars received "D" grades. The damage ranged from minor cosmetic
flaws caused by normal weathering to holes and fissures severe enough to
constitute a walking hazard. At least 778 stars will eventually be repaired or
replaced during the ongoing project at an estimated cost of $4 million to $4.2
million.[47]

The restoration is a collaboration among the Hollywood Chamber of Commerce and
various Los Angeles city and county governmental offices, along with the MTA,
which operates the [Metro Red Line](/wiki/Red_Line_\(Los_Angeles_Metro\) "Red
Line \(Los Angeles Metro\)") that runs beneath the Walk, since earth movement
due to the presence of the subway line is thought to be partly responsible for
the damage.[48]

To encourage supplemental funding for the project by corporate sponsors, the
"Friends of Walk of Fame" program was inaugurated.[47] [Absolut
Vodka](/wiki/Absolut_Vodka "Absolut Vodka") became the first Friend with a
donation of $1 million,[49][50] followed by [L'Oréal](/wiki/L%27Or%C3%A9al
"L'Oréal").[51] Friends are recognized with honorary plaques adjacent to the
Walk of Fame in front of the Dolby Theatre.[10] The program received some
criticism. [Alana Semuels](/wiki/Alana_Semuels "Alana Semuels") of the _[Los
Angeles Times](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times "Los Angeles Times")_ described it as
"just the latest corporate attempt to buy some good buzz," and, quoting an
area brand strategist, "I think Johnny Grant would roll over in his
grave."[10] Karen Fondu, President of L'Oréal Paris, countered that the
association was "a natural affinity."[50]

## The Walk of Fame
today[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: The Walk of Fame today")]

### Multiple
stars[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Multiple stars")]

The original selection committees chose to recognize some entertainers'
contributions in multiple categories with multiple stars. [Gene
Autry](/wiki/Gene_Autry "Gene Autry") is the only honoree with stars in all
five categories.[52][53] [Bob Hope](/wiki/Bob_Hope "Bob Hope"), [Mickey
Rooney](/wiki/Mickey_Rooney "Mickey Rooney"), [Roy Rogers](/wiki/Roy_Rogers
"Roy Rogers"), and [Tony Martin](/wiki/Tony_Martin_\(American_singer\) "Tony
Martin \(American singer\)") each have stars in four categories—Rooney has
three of his own and a fourth with his eighth and final wife, Jan,[54][55]
while Rogers also has three of his own, and a fourth with his band, [Sons of
the Pioneers](/wiki/Sons_of_the_Pioneers "Sons of the Pioneers").[56][57]
Thirty-three people, including [Bing Crosby](/wiki/Bing_Crosby "Bing Crosby"),
[Frank Sinatra](/wiki/Frank_Sinatra "Frank Sinatra"), [Jo
Stafford](/wiki/Jo_Stafford "Jo Stafford"), [Dean Martin](/wiki/Dean_Martin
"Dean Martin"), [Dinah Shore](/wiki/Dinah_Shore "Dinah Shore"), [Gale
Storm](/wiki/Gale_Storm "Gale Storm"), [Danny Kaye](/wiki/Danny_Kaye "Danny
Kaye"), [Douglas Fairbanks Jr.](/wiki/Douglas_Fairbanks_Jr. "Douglas Fairbanks
Jr."), and [Jack Benny](/wiki/Jack_Benny "Jack Benny"), have stars in three
categories.[52]

Seven recording artists have two stars in the same category for distinct
achievements: [Michael Jackson](/wiki/Michael_Jackson "Michael Jackson"), as a
soloist and as a member of [The Jackson 5](/wiki/The_Jackson_5 "The Jackson
5"); [Diana Ross](/wiki/Diana_Ross "Diana Ross"), as a member of [The
Supremes](/wiki/The_Supremes "The Supremes") and for her solo work; [Smokey
Robinson](/wiki/Smokey_Robinson "Smokey Robinson"), as a solo artist and as a
member of [The Miracles](/wiki/The_Miracles "The Miracles"); and [John
Lennon](/wiki/John_Lennon "John Lennon"), [Ringo Starr](/wiki/Ringo_Starr
"Ringo Starr"), [George Harrison](/wiki/George_Harrison "George Harrison"),
and [Paul McCartney](/wiki/Paul_McCartney "Paul McCartney") as individuals and
as members of [The Beatles](/wiki/The_Beatles "The Beatles").[58]
[Cher](/wiki/Cher "Cher") forfeited her opportunity by declining to schedule
the mandatory personal appearance when she was selected in 1983.[59] She did
attend the unveiling of the [Sonny & Cher](/wiki/Sonny_%26_Cher "Sonny &
Cher") star in 1998 as a tribute to her recently deceased ex-husband, [Sonny
Bono](/wiki/Sonny_Bono "Sonny Bono").[60]

[George Eastman](/wiki/George_Eastman "George Eastman") is the only honoree
with two stars in the same category for the same achievement, the invention of
[roll film](/wiki/Roll_film "Roll film").[61]

In 1977, country singer [Loretta Lynn](/wiki/Loretta_Lynn "Loretta Lynn") was
the first of her genre to receive a star on the Walk of Fame.

### Controversial
additions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Controversial additions")]

[![Photograph of Charlie Chaplin's star on the Walk of
Fame](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Walk_of_fames_Charlie.jpg/170px-
Walk_of_fames_Charlie.jpg)](/wiki/File:Walk_of_fames_Charlie.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Walk_of_fames_Charlie.jpg "Enlarge")

Charlie Chaplin's star, selected in 1956, installed in 1972

[Charlie Chaplin](/wiki/Charlie_Chaplin "Charlie Chaplin") is the only honoree
to be selected twice for the same star on the Walk. He was unanimously voted
into the initial group of 500 in 1956 but the Selection Committee ultimately
excluded him, ostensibly due to questions regarding his morals (he had been
charged with violating the [Mann Act](/wiki/Mann_Act "Mann Act")—and
exonerated—during the [White Slavery](/wiki/Sexual_slavery#White_slavery
"Sexual slavery") hysteria of the 1940s[62]), but more likely due to his left-
leaning political views.[63] The rebuke prompted an unsuccessful lawsuit by
his son, Charles Chaplin Jr. His star was finally added to the Walk in 1972,
the same year he received his [Academy Award](/wiki/Academy_Awards "Academy
Awards");[24] but even then, 16 years later, the Chamber of Commerce received
angry letters from across the country protesting its decision to include
him.[64]

The committee's Chaplin difficulties reportedly contributed to its decision in
1978 against awarding a star to [Paul Robeson](/wiki/Paul_Robeson "Paul
Robeson"), a controversial opera singer, actor, athlete, writer, lawyer, and
social activist.[65] The resulting outcry from the entertainment industry,
civic circles, local and national politicians, and many other quarters was so
intense that the decision was reversed and Robeson was awarded a star in
1979.[66][67][68]

Following sexual assault allegations involving comedian [Bill
Cosby](/wiki/Bill_Cosby "Bill Cosby"), actor [Kevin Spacey](/wiki/Kevin_Spacey
"Kevin Spacey"), reality television host [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump
"Donald Trump"), and producer-director [Brett Ratner](/wiki/Brett_Ratner
"Brett Ratner"), the Hollywood Chamber of Commerce released a statement
regarding inquiries as to the removal of stars:[69]

> The Hollywood Chamber of Commerce has received inquiries asking whether we
> are planning to remove the stars of Walk of Famers because of alleged
> misconduct. The answer is no...The Hollywood Walk of Fame is a registered
> historic landmark. Once a star has been added to the Walk, it is considered
> a part of the historic fabric of the Hollywood Walk of Fame. Because of
> this, we have never removed a star from the Walk.[69]

As of 2018, this has been the Hollywood Chamber of Commerce's only statement
regarding the removal of stars.

On August 6, 2018, the West Hollywood City Council passed a resolution asking
for the removal of the star for Donald Trump, after repeated vandalism to the
site. The Mayor of West Hollywood, John Duran, stated that "the council
unanimously passes the resolution to remove his star"; however, the West
Hollywood City Council has no jurisdiction over the Walk of Fame.[70]

### Stars with the same
name[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Stars with the same name")]

Two pairs of stars share identical names representing different people. There
are two Harrison Ford stars, honoring [the silent film
actor](/wiki/Harrison_Ford_\(silent_film_actor\) "Harrison Ford \(silent film
actor\)") (at 6665 Hollywood Boulevard), and [the present-day
actor](/wiki/Harrison_Ford "Harrison Ford") (in front of the Dolby Theatre at
6801 Hollywood Boulevard). Two Michael Jackson stars represent the
[singer/dancer/songwriter](/wiki/Michael_Jackson "Michael Jackson") (at 6927
Hollywood Boulevard), and the [radio
personality](/wiki/Michael_Jackson_\(radio_commentator\) "Michael Jackson
\(radio commentator\)") (at 1597 Vine Street). When the recording artist
Jackson died in 2009, fans mistakenly began leaving flowers, candles, and
other tributes at the Vine Street star.[71] Upon learning of this, the radio
host wrote on his website, "I am willingly loan[ing] it to him and, if it
would bring him back, he can have it."[72]

The most common surname, with sixteen stars, is Williams: [Andy
Williams](/wiki/Andy_Williams "Andy Williams"), [Bill
Williams](/wiki/Bill_Williams_\(actor\) "Bill Williams \(actor\)"), [Billy Dee
Williams](/wiki/Billy_Dee_Williams "Billy Dee Williams"), [Cindy
Williams](/wiki/Cindy_Williams "Cindy Williams"), [Earle
Williams](/wiki/Earle_Williams "Earle Williams"), [Esther
Williams](/wiki/Esther_Williams "Esther Williams"), [Guy
Williams](/wiki/Guy_Williams_\(actor\) "Guy Williams \(actor\)"), [Hank
Williams](/wiki/Hank_Williams "Hank Williams"), [Joe
Williams](/wiki/Joe_Williams_\(jazz_singer\) "Joe Williams \(jazz singer\)"),
[Kathlyn Williams](/wiki/Kathlyn_Williams "Kathlyn Williams"), [Paul
Williams](/wiki/Paul_Williams_\(songwriter\) "Paul Williams \(songwriter\)"),
[Pharrell Williams](/wiki/Pharrell_Williams "Pharrell Williams"), [Robin
Williams](/wiki/Robin_Williams "Robin Williams"), [Roger
Williams](/wiki/Roger_Williams_\(pianist\) "Roger Williams \(pianist\)"), [Tex
Williams](/wiki/Tex_Williams "Tex Williams") and [Vanessa
Williams](/wiki/Vanessa_Williams "Vanessa Williams").[73] There are fourteen
stars with the surname Moore, twelve with Jones, and seven with Smith.

The largest collection of stars honoring one group of blood relatives is the
widely scattered set of seven representing the Barrymore family: [John
Barrymore](/wiki/John_Barrymore "John Barrymore"), his brother
[Lionel](/wiki/Lionel_Barrymore "Lionel Barrymore") (who has two), and sister
[Ethel](/wiki/Ethel_Barrymore "Ethel Barrymore"), their uncle [Sidney
Drew](/wiki/Mr._and_Mrs._Sidney_Drew "Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Drew"), John's son
[John Drew Barrymore](/wiki/John_Drew_Barrymore "John Drew Barrymore"), and
John Drew's daughter [Drew Barrymore](/wiki/Drew_Barrymore "Drew Barrymore").

### Bending the
rules[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Bending the rules")]

[![Moon Landing monument, with square pink terrazzo surround \(not the usual
charcoal color\), with light gray terrazzo Moon disk showing TV emblem at top
and the brass lettering "Neil A. Armstrong, Edwin E. Aldrin and Michael
Collins, 7/20/69, Apollo
XI"](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/HollywoodWalkOfFameMoonAtHollywoodAndVine.jpg/220px-
HollywoodWalkOfFameMoonAtHollywoodAndVine.jpg)](/wiki/File:HollywoodWalkOfFameMoonAtHollywoodAndVine.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:HollywoodWalkOfFameMoonAtHollywoodAndVine.jpg "Enlarge")

One of the four monuments recognizing the Apollo 11 astronauts at the corners
of Hollywood and Vine

Walk of Fame rules prohibit consideration of nominees whose contributions fall
outside the five major entertainment categories, but the selection committee
has been known to conjure some interesting rule interpretations to justify a
selection. The Walk's four round Moon landing monuments at the corners of
Hollywood and Vine, for example, officially recognize the [Apollo
11](/wiki/Apollo_11 "Apollo 11") astronauts for "contributions to the
television industry". Johnny Grant acknowledged, in 2005, that classifying the
first Moon landing as a television entertainment event was "a bit of a
stretch". [Magic Johnson](/wiki/Magic_Johnson "Magic Johnson")'s considerable
[basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball") skills had no direct connection to
movies, music, TV, radio, or theater, but the committee added him to the
motion picture category, based on his ownership of the [Magic Johnson
Theatre](/wiki/Magic_Johnson_Theatres "Magic Johnson Theatres") chain, citing
as precedent [Sid Grauman](/wiki/Sid_Grauman "Sid Grauman"), builder of
Grauman's (now [TCL](/wiki/TCL_Chinese_Theatre "TCL Chinese Theatre")) Chinese
Theatre. "[Now] people want [Orville Redenbacher](/wiki/Orville_Redenbacher
"Orville Redenbacher")," Grant quipped in the 2005 interview, "because his
popcorn is in all the theaters."[25]

[Muhammad Ali](/wiki/Muhammad_Ali "Muhammad Ali")'s star was granted after the
committee decided that [boxing](/wiki/Boxing "Boxing") could be considered a
form of "live performance". Its placement, on a wall of the Dolby Theatre,
makes it the only star mounted on a vertical surface, acceding to Ali's
request that his name not be walked upon.[74][75]

All living honorees have been required since 1968 to personally attend their
star's unveiling, and approximately 40 have declined the honor due to this
condition.[25] The only recipient to date who failed to appear after agreeing
to do so was [Barbra Streisand](/wiki/Barbra_Streisand "Barbra Streisand"), in
1976. Her star was unveiled anyway, near the intersection of Hollywood and
Highland.[76] Streisand did attend when her husband, [James
Brolin](/wiki/James_Brolin "James Brolin"), unveiled his star in 1998 two
blocks to the east.[77]

### Unique and
unusual[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Unique and unusual")]

Fifteen stars are identified with a one-word [stage name](/wiki/Stage_name
"Stage name"): [Cantinflas](/wiki/Cantinflas "Cantinflas"),
[Houdini](/wiki/Harry_Houdini "Harry Houdini"), [Liberace](/wiki/Liberace
"Liberace"), [Mako](/wiki/Mako_\(actor\) "Mako \(actor\)"),
[Meiklejohn](/wiki/William_Meiklejohn "William Meiklejohn"),
[Paderewski](/wiki/Ignacy_Jan_Paderewski "Ignacy Jan Paderewski"),
[Parkyakarkus](/wiki/Harry_Einstein "Harry Einstein"),
[Roseanne](/wiki/Roseanne_Barr "Roseanne Barr"), [RuPaul](/wiki/RuPaul
"RuPaul"), [Sabu](/wiki/Sabu_Dastagir "Sabu Dastagir"),
[Shakira](/wiki/Shakira "Shakira"), [Slash](/wiki/Slash_\(musician\) "Slash
\(musician\)"), [Sting](/wiki/Sting_\(musician\) "Sting \(musician\)"),
[Thalía](/wiki/Thal%C3%ADa "Thalía"), and [Usher](/wiki/Usher_\(musician\)
"Usher \(musician\)").

The largest group of individuals represented by a single star is the estimated
122 adults and 12 children[78] collectively known as the
[Munchkins](/wiki/Munchkin "Munchkin"), from the landmark 1939 film _[The
Wizard of Oz](/wiki/The_Wizard_of_Oz_\(1939_film\) "The Wizard of Oz \(1939
film\)")_.

[Clayton Moore](/wiki/Clayton_Moore "Clayton Moore") is so inextricably linked
with his [Lone Ranger](/wiki/Lone_Ranger "Lone Ranger") character, even though
he played other roles during his career, that he is one of only two actors to
have his character's name alongside his own on his star. The other is [Tommy
Riggs](/wiki/Tommy_Riggs_and_Betty_Lou "Tommy Riggs and Betty Lou"), whose
star reads, "Tommy Riggs & Betty Lou."[79]

For more than 40 years, singer [Jimmy Boyd](/wiki/Jimmy_Boyd "Jimmy Boyd") was
the youngest star recipient at age 20, but he lost that distinction in 2004 to
18-year-old twins [Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen](/wiki/Mary-
Kate_and_Ashley_Olsen "Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen"). Their joint star (the
only one shared by twins) is outside the Dolby Theatre, near the [Hollywood
and Highland Center](/wiki/Hollywood_and_Highland "Hollywood and Highland").

[The Westmores](/wiki/Westmore_family "Westmore family") received the first
star honoring contributions in [theatrical make-up](/wiki/Theatrical_makeup
"Theatrical makeup"). Other make-up artists on the walk are [Max
Factor](/wiki/Max_Factor "Max Factor"), [John
Chambers](/wiki/John_Chambers_\(make-up_artist\) "John Chambers \(make-up
artist\)") and [Rick Baker](/wiki/Rick_Baker "Rick Baker"). Three stars
recognize experts in [special effects](/wiki/Special_Effects_\(film\) "Special
Effects \(film\)"): [Ray Harryhausen](/wiki/Ray_Harryhausen "Ray
Harryhausen"), [Dennis Muren](/wiki/Dennis_Muren "Dennis Muren"), and [Stan
Winston](/wiki/Stan_Winston "Stan Winston"). Only one [costume
designer](/wiki/Costume_design "Costume design") has received a star, eight-
time Academy Award winner [Edith Head](/wiki/Edith_Head "Edith Head").

[Sidney Sheldon](/wiki/Sidney_Sheldon "Sidney Sheldon") is one of two
novelists with a star, which he earned for writing screenplays such as _The
Bachelor and the Bobby-Soxer_ before turning to novels.[80] The other is [Ray
Bradbury](/wiki/Ray_Bradbury "Ray Bradbury"), whose books and stories have
formed the basis of dozens of movies and television programs over a nearly
60-year period.[81]

Ten [inventors](/wiki/Inventor "Inventor") have stars on the Walk: George
Eastman (as mentioned); [Thomas Edison](/wiki/Thomas_Edison "Thomas Edison"),
inventor of the first true film projector and holder of numerous patents
related to motion-picture technology; [Lee de Forest](/wiki/Lee_de_Forest "Lee
de Forest"), inventor of the [vacuum tube](/wiki/Vacuum_tube "Vacuum tube"),
which made radio and TV possible, and [Phonofilm](/wiki/Phonofilm
"Phonofilm"), which made sound movies possible; [Merian C.
Cooper](/wiki/Merian_C._Cooper "Merian C. Cooper"), co-inventor of the
[Cinerama](/wiki/Cinerama "Cinerama") process; [Herbert
Kalmus](/wiki/Herbert_Kalmus "Herbert Kalmus"), inventor of
[Technicolor](/wiki/Technicolor "Technicolor"); [Auguste and Louis
Lumière](/wiki/Auguste_and_Louis_Lumi%C3%A8re "Auguste and Louis Lumière"),
inventors of important components of the motion picture camera; [Mark
Serrurier](/wiki/Mark_Serrurier "Mark Serrurier"), inventor of the technology
used for film editing; [Hedy Lamarr](/wiki/Hedy_Lamarr "Hedy Lamarr"), co-
inventor of a [frequency-hopping](/wiki/Frequency-hopping_spread_spectrum
"Frequency-hopping spread spectrum") radio guidance system that was a
precursor to [Wi-Fi](/wiki/Wi-Fi "Wi-Fi") networks and [cellular
telephone](/wiki/Cellular_telephone "Cellular telephone") systems;[82] and
[Ray Dolby](/wiki/Ray_Dolby "Ray Dolby"), co-developer of the [video tape
recorder](/wiki/Video_tape_recorder "Video tape recorder") and inventor of the
[Dolby noise reduction system](/wiki/Dolby_noise_reduction_system "Dolby noise
reduction system").

A few star recipients moved on after their entertainment careers to political
notability. Two [Presidents of the United
States](/wiki/Presidents_of_the_United_States "Presidents of the United
States"), [Ronald Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan") (40th
President) and [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") (45th
President) have stars on the Walk. Reagan is also one of two [Governors of
California](/wiki/Governor_of_California "Governor of California") with a
star; the other is [Arnold Schwarzenegger](/wiki/Arnold_Schwarzenegger "Arnold
Schwarzenegger").[83] One [U.S. senator](/wiki/U.S._senator "U.S. senator")
([George Murphy](/wiki/George_Murphy "George Murphy")) and two members of the
[U.S. House of Representatives](/wiki/U.S._House_of_Representatives "U.S.
House of Representatives") ([Helen Gahagan](/wiki/Helen_Gahagan_Douglas "Helen
Gahagan Douglas") and Sonny Bono) have stars. [Ignacy
Paderewski](/wiki/Ignacy_Jan_Paderewski "Ignacy Jan Paderewski"), who served
as Prime Minister of Poland between the World Wars, is the only European [head
of government](/wiki/Head_of_government "Head of government") represented.
Film and stage actor [Albert Dekker](/wiki/Albert_Dekker "Albert Dekker")
served one term in the [California State
Assembly](/wiki/California_State_Assembly "California State Assembly") during
the 1940s,[84] which was notable for his outspoken public criticism of Senator
[Joseph McCarthy](/wiki/Joseph_McCarthy "Joseph McCarthy")'s anti-communism
demagoguery, leading to his [blacklisting](/wiki/Hollywood_blacklist
"Hollywood blacklist").[85]

On its 50th anniversary in 2005, [Disneyland](/wiki/Disneyland "Disneyland")
received a star adjacent to the Walk of Fame near Disney's Soda Fountain on
Hollywood Boulevard. While not technically part of the Hollywood Walk of Fame
(a city ordinance prohibits putting corporate names on sidewalks), the star
was installed adjacent to the Walk of Fame, and was thought of by [Johnny
Grant](/wiki/Johnny_Grant_\(radio_personality\) "Johnny Grant \(radio
personality\)"), the proverbial "Mayor of Hollywood." [Roger
Ebert](/wiki/Roger_Ebert "Roger Ebert") said of the star "If you stop to think
about what Disneyland has achieved and what a revolutionary idea it was to
begin with, of course it deserve[s] a star." In lieu of the traditional icon
indicating the specific achievement(s) of the honoree, Disneyland's star has
an icon of [Sleeping Beauty Castle](/wiki/Sleeping_Beauty_Castle "Sleeping
Beauty Castle"), and a plaque beneath the star reading: "Award of Excellence
Special achievement for 50 years of magical entertainment Hollywood Historic
Trust July 14, 2005. Johnny Grant, Chairman."[86]

### Fictional characters and their
creators[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Fictional characters and their creators")]

Main article: [List of fictional characters with stars on the Hollywood Walk
of
Fame](/wiki/List_of_fictional_characters_with_stars_on_the_Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame
"List of fictional characters with stars on the Hollywood Walk of Fame")

[![closeup of Mickey Mouse star, showing title and Motion Picture
emblem](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Mickey_Mouse_star_in_Walk_of_Fame.jpg/220px-
Mickey_Mouse_star_in_Walk_of_Fame.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mickey_Mouse_star_in_Walk_of_Fame.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mickey_Mouse_star_in_Walk_of_Fame.jpg "Enlarge")

Mickey Mouse's star was the first awarded to an animated character

In 1978, in honor of his 50th anniversary, [Mickey Mouse](/wiki/Mickey_Mouse
"Mickey Mouse") became the first animated character to receive a star. Other
animated recipients are [Bugs Bunny](/wiki/Bugs_Bunny "Bugs Bunny"), [Donald
Duck](/wiki/Donald_Duck "Donald Duck"), [Minnie Mouse](/wiki/Minnie_Mouse
"Minnie Mouse"), [Woody Woodpecker](/wiki/Woody_Woodpecker "Woody
Woodpecker"), [Snow White](/wiki/Snow_White_\(Disney_character\) "Snow White
\(Disney character\)"), [Tinker Bell](/wiki/Tinker_Bell "Tinker Bell"),
[Winnie the Pooh](/wiki/Winnie_the_Pooh_\(Disney_character\) "Winnie the Pooh
\(Disney character\)"), [Shrek](/wiki/Shrek_\(character\) "Shrek
\(character\)"), [The Simpsons](/wiki/The_Simpsons "The Simpsons"), the
[Rugrats](/wiki/Rugrats "Rugrats"), and [Snoopy](/wiki/Snoopy "Snoopy"). The
star inscribed [Charlie Tuna](/wiki/Charlie_Tuna "Charlie Tuna") honors not
the animated advertising mascot, but Art Ferguson, the long-time radio
personality and game show announcer.

Other fictional characters on the Walk include the Munchkins (as mentioned),
two individual [Muppets](/wiki/The_Muppets "The Muppets") ([Kermit the
Frog](/wiki/Kermit_the_Frog "Kermit the Frog") and [Big Bird](/wiki/Big_Bird
"Big Bird")) and the Muppets as a group, one monster
([Godzilla](/wiki/Godzilla "Godzilla")), and three non-animated canine
characters ([Strongheart](/wiki/Strongheart "Strongheart"),
[Lassie](/wiki/Lassie "Lassie"), and [Rin Tin Tin](/wiki/Rin_Tin_Tin "Rin Tin
Tin")).

Ten stars recognize cartoonists and animators: Walt Disney, [Chuck
Jones](/wiki/Chuck_Jones "Chuck Jones"), [Friz Freleng](/wiki/Friz_Freleng
"Friz Freleng"), Walter Lantz, [Hanna–Barbera](/wiki/Hanna%E2%80%93Barbera
"Hanna–Barbera"), [Charles M. Schulz](/wiki/Charles_M._Schulz "Charles M.
Schulz"), [Jay Ward](/wiki/Jay_Ward "Jay Ward"), [Dr. Seuss](/wiki/Dr._Seuss
"Dr. Seuss"), [Matt Groening](/wiki/Matt_Groening "Matt Groening") and [John
Lasseter](/wiki/John_Lasseter "John Lasseter").[87] Two puppeteers have stars:
[Jim Henson](/wiki/Jim_Henson "Jim Henson") and [Shari
Lewis](/wiki/Shari_Lewis "Shari Lewis"), as does [Fran
Allison](/wiki/Fran_Allison "Fran Allison"), who appeared with [Burr
Tillstrom](/wiki/Burr_Tillstrom "Burr Tillstrom")'s puppets on the TV show
_[Kukla, Fran and Ollie](/wiki/Kukla,_Fran_and_Ollie "Kukla, Fran and
Ollie")_.

### Star
locations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Star locations")]

Locations of individual stars are not necessarily random or arbitrary. Stars
of most legendary and world-famous celebrities—the so-called "show business
royalty"—are found in front of TCL (formerly Grauman's) Chinese Theatre.
Oscar-winners' stars are usually placed near the Dolby Theatre, site of the
annual [Academy Awards](/wiki/Academy_Awards "Academy Awards") presentations.
Decisions are occasionally made with a dollop of whimsy: [Mike
Myers](/wiki/Mike_Myers "Mike Myers")'s star, for example, lies in front of an
adult store called the International Love Boutique, an association with his
[Austin Powers](/wiki/Austin_Powers_\(film_series\) "Austin Powers \(film
series\)") roles; [Roger Moore](/wiki/Roger_Moore "Roger Moore")'s star is
located at 7007 Hollywood Boulevard in recognition of his seven [James Bond
007](/wiki/James_Bond_007 "James Bond 007") films; [Ed
O'Neill](/wiki/Ed_O%27Neill "Ed O'Neill")'s star is located outside a shoe
store in reference to his character's occupation on the TV show _[Married...
with Children](/wiki/Married..._with_Children "Married... with Children")_
;[88] and the last star, at the very end of the westernmost portion of the
Walk, belongs to The [Dead End Kids](/wiki/Dead_End_Kids "Dead End Kids").

Honorees may request a specific location for their star, although final
decisions remain with the Chamber.[25] [Jay Leno](/wiki/Jay_Leno "Jay Leno"),
for example, requested a spot near the corner of Hollywood Blvd. and Highland
Ave. because he was twice picked up at that location by police for
[vagrancy](/wiki/Vagrancy_\(people\) "Vagrancy \(people\)") (though never
actually charged) shortly after his arrival in Hollywood.[89] George Carlin
chose to have his star placed in front of the KDAY radio station near the
corner of Sunset Blvd. and Vine St., where he first gained national
recognition.[90] [Carol Burnett](/wiki/Carol_Burnett "Carol Burnett")
explained her choice in her 1986 memoir: While working as an usherette at the
historic Warner Brothers Theatre (now the [Hollywood Pacific
Theatre](/wiki/Hollywood_Pacific_Theatre "Hollywood Pacific Theatre")) during
the 1951 run of [Alfred Hitchcock](/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock "Alfred
Hitchcock")'s film _[Strangers on a Train](/wiki/Strangers_on_a_Train_\(film\)
"Strangers on a Train \(film\)")_ , she took it upon herself to advise a
couple arriving during the final few minutes of a showing to wait for the next
showing, to avoid seeing (and spoiling) the ending. The theater manager fired
her on the spot for "insubordination" and humiliated her by stripping the
epaulets from her uniform in the theater lobby. Twenty-six years later, at her
request, Burnett's star was placed at the corner of Hollywood and Wilcox—in
front of the theater.[91]

### Errors and
mysteries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Errors and mysteries")]

In 2010, [Julia Louis-Dreyfus](/wiki/Julia_Louis-Dreyfus "Julia Louis-
Dreyfus")'s star was constructed with the name "Julia Luis Dreyfus".[92] The
actress was reportedly amused, and the error was corrected.[93] A similar
mistake was made on [Dick Van Dyke](/wiki/Dick_Van_Dyke "Dick Van Dyke")'s
star in 1993 ("Vandyke"), and rectified.[94]

[![Monty Woolley's star, showing a "TV" emblem, even though his category is
"Motion
Pictures"](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Monty_Woolley_star_HWF.JPG/220px-
Monty_Woolley_star_HWF.JPG)](/wiki/File:Monty_Woolley_star_HWF.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Monty_Woolley_star_HWF.JPG "Enlarge")

"Motion Picture" category, "TV" emblem

Film and television actor [Don Haggerty](/wiki/Don_Haggerty "Don Haggerty")'s
star originally displayed the first name "Dan". The mistake was fixed, but
years later the television actor [Dan Haggerty](/wiki/Dan_Haggerty "Dan
Haggerty") (of _[Grizzly Adams](/wiki/The_Life_and_Times_of_Grizzly_Adams "The
Life and Times of Grizzly Adams")_ fame, no relation to Don) also received a
star. The confusion eventually sprouted an [urban legend](/wiki/Urban_legend
"Urban legend") that Dan Haggerty was the only honoree to have a star removed
from the Walk of Fame.[95][96]

For 28 years, the star intended to honor [Mauritz
Stiller](/wiki/Mauritz_Stiller "Mauritz Stiller"), the Helsinki-born pioneer
of Swedish film who brought [Greta Garbo](/wiki/Greta_Garbo "Greta Garbo") to
the United States, read "Maurice Diller", possibly due to mistranscription of
verbal dictation. The star was finally remade with the correct name in
1988.[97][98]

Three stars remain misspelled: opera diva [Lotte Lehmann](/wiki/Lotte_Lehmann
"Lotte Lehmann")'s first name is spelled "Lottie";[99]
[Cinerama](/wiki/Cinerama "Cinerama") co-inventor and _[King
Kong](/wiki/King_Kong_\(1933_film\) "King Kong \(1933 film\)")_ creator,
director, and producer [Merian C. Cooper](/wiki/Merian_C._Cooper "Merian C.
Cooper")'s first name is spelled "Meriam";[100][101] and cinematography
pioneer [Auguste Lumière](/wiki/Auguste_Lumi%C3%A8re "Auguste Lumière")'s
first name is listed as "August".[102]

[Monty Woolley](/wiki/Monty_Woolley "Monty Woolley"), the veteran film and
stage actor best known for [_The Man Who Came to
Dinner_](/wiki/The_Man_Who_Came_to_Dinner_\(film\) "The Man Who Came to Dinner
\(film\)") (1942) and the classic line "Time flies when you're having fun", is
officially listed in the motion picture category,[103] but his star on the
Walk of Fame bears the television emblem.[104] Woolley did appear on the small
screen late in his career, but his TV contributions were eclipsed by his
extensive stage, film, and radio work.[105][106][107] Similarly, the star of
film actress [Carmen Miranda](/wiki/Carmen_Miranda "Carmen Miranda") bears the
TV emblem,[108] although her official category is motion pictures.[109] Radio
and television talk show host [Larry King](/wiki/Larry_King "Larry King") is
officially a television honoree,[110] but his star displays a film
camera.[111]

The _Los Angeles Times_ , which documented and photographed the Walk as part
of its Hollywood Star Walk project, reported that it could not find two stars,
honoring [Richard Crooks](/wiki/Richard_Crooks "Richard Crooks") and the film
career of [Geraldine Farrar](/wiki/Geraldine_Farrar "Geraldine
Farrar").[112][113][114] (Farrar's music star is located on the 1700 block of
Vine Street.)

### Theft and
vandalism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Theft and vandalism")]

Acts of vandalism occur on the Walk on a regular basis, ranging from profanity
and political statements written on stars with markers to attempted removal of
brass emblems with chisels.[115] Closed circuit surveillance cameras have been
installed on the stretch of Hollywood Boulevard between La Brea Avenue and
Vine Street in an effort to discourage mischievous activities.[116]

Four of the stars, which weigh about 300 pounds (140 kg) each, have been
stolen from the Walk of Fame. In 2000, [James Stewart](/wiki/James_Stewart
"James Stewart")'s and [Kirk Douglas](/wiki/Kirk_Douglas "Kirk Douglas")'s
stars disappeared from their locations near the intersection of Hollywood and
Vine, where they had been temporarily removed for a construction project.
Police recovered them in the suburban community of [South
Gate](/wiki/South_Gate,_California "South Gate, California") when they
arrested a man involved in an incident there and searched his house. The
suspect was a construction worker employed on the Hollywood and Vine project.
The stars had been badly damaged, and had to be remade. One of [Gene
Autry](/wiki/Gene_Autry "Gene Autry")'s five stars (it is not clear which one)
was also stolen from a construction area. Johnny Grant later received an
anonymous phone tip that the missing star was in Iowa, but it was never found.
"Someday, it will end up on eBay," Grant once joked. The most brazen and
ambitious theft occurred in 2005 when thieves used a [concrete
saw](/wiki/Concrete_saw "Concrete saw") to remove [Gregory
Peck](/wiki/Gregory_Peck "Gregory Peck")'s star from its Hollywood Boulevard
site at the intersection of North El Centro Avenue, near North Gower. The star
was replaced almost immediately, but the original was never recovered and the
perpetrators never caught.[117]

In late 2009, rumors circulated widely on media outlets and the Internet that
John Lennon's star had been stolen, but it was merely being relocated farther
south on Vine Street to an area near the circular [Capitol Records
Building](/wiki/Capitol_Records_Building "Capitol Records Building"), adjacent
to the stars of bandmates George Harrison and Ringo Starr.[118] Paul
McCartney's star was installed in the same location in 2012.[119]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Donald_Trump%27s_Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame_Star_being_repaired.jpg/220px-
Donald_Trump%27s_Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame_Star_being_repaired.jpg)](/wiki/File:Donald_Trump%27s_Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame_Star_being_repaired.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Donald_Trump%27s_Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame_Star_being_repaired.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump")'s star was repaired soon
after it was destroyed on July 25, 2018.

[Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump")'s star—received as host of
_[The Apprentice](/wiki/The_Apprentice_\(U.S._TV_series\) "The Apprentice
\(U.S. TV series\)")_ television series—was repeatedly defaced during the 2016
presidential campaign.[120][121][122] In late October, near the end of the
race, a man named Jamie Otis (who claimed to be an heir to the [Otis
Elevator](/wiki/Otis_Elevator "Otis Elevator") fortune) used a sledge hammer
and a pickaxe to destroy all of the star's brass inlays. He readily admitted
to the vandalism, which he described as "civil disobedience" and "freedom of
expression", and told reporters that he originally planned to remove the
entire star and auction it to raise money for the women who accused Trump of
sexually assaulting them.[123] Otis was arrested three weeks after the
incident, charged with one count of felony vandalism,[124] and sentenced to
three years' probation plus $3,400 in restitution payments.[125] The star
itself was repaired, serving as the site of pro-Trump demonstrations[126]
until it was destroyed a second time in July 2018 by a man named Austin
Clay.[127] Clay later surrendered himself to the police and was bailed out by
Jamie Otis.[128][129]

### Four Ladies of
Hollywood[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Four Ladies of Hollywood")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/52/Four_Ladies_of_Hollywood_2008.jpg/170px-
Four_Ladies_of_Hollywood_2008.jpg)](/wiki/File:Four_Ladies_of_Hollywood_2008.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Four_Ladies_of_Hollywood_2008.jpg "Enlarge")

The Four Ladies of Hollywood gazebo at the Walk of Fame's west end

The Four Ladies of Hollywood [gazebo](/wiki/Gazebo "Gazebo")[130]—known
officially as the Hollywood and La Brea Gateway[131]—stands upon a small
triangular island formed by the confluence of Hollywood Boulevard, Marshfield
Way, and North La Brea Avenue at the westernmost extension of the Walk of
Fame. It was commissioned in 1993 by the Los Angeles Community Redevelopment
Agency Art Program and created by the architect, production designer, and film
director [Catherine Hardwicke](/wiki/Catherine_Hardwicke "Catherine
Hardwicke") as a tribute to the multi-ethnic women of Hollywood.[131] The
gazebo is a stainless steel stylized [Art Deco](/wiki/Art_Deco "Art Deco")
lattice structure. The roof is an arched square supporting a circular dome,
which is topped by a central [obelisk](/wiki/Obelisk "Obelisk") with
descending [neon](/wiki/Neon_sign "Neon sign") block letters spelling
"Hollywood" on each of its four sides. Atop the obelisk is a small gilded
weathervane-style sculpture of [Marilyn Monroe](/wiki/Marilyn_Monroe "Marilyn
Monroe") in her iconic billowing skirt pose from _[The Seven Year
Itch](/wiki/The_Seven_Year_Itch "The Seven Year Itch")_.[132] The domed
structure is held aloft by four [caryatids](/wiki/Caryatid "Caryatid")
sculpted by Harl West[131] to represent the African-American actress [Dorothy
Dandridge](/wiki/Dorothy_Dandridge "Dorothy Dandridge"), Asian-American
actress [Anna May Wong](/wiki/Anna_May_Wong "Anna May Wong"), Mexican actress
[Dolores del Río](/wiki/Dolores_del_R%C3%ADo "Dolores del Río"), and the
multi-ethnic, Brooklyn-born actress [Mae West](/wiki/Mae_West "Mae
West").[130]

The gazebo was dedicated on February 1, 1994, to a mixed reception. _[Los
Angeles Times](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times "Los Angeles Times")_ art critic
Christopher Knight called it "the most depressingly awful work of public art
in recent years", representing the opposite of Hardwicke's intended tribute to
women. "Sex, as a woman's historic gateway to Hollywood", he wrote, "couldn't
be more explicitly described".[133] Independent writer and film producer Gail
Choice called it a fitting tribute to a group of pioneering and courageous
women who "carried a tremendous burden on their feminine shoulders. Never in
my wildest dreams did I believe I'd ever see [women of
color](/wiki/Women_of_color "Women of color") immortalized in such a creative
and wonderful fashion."[134] Hardwicke contended that critics had missed the
"humor and symbolism" of the structure, which "embraces and pokes fun at the
glamour, the polished metallic male form of the [Oscar](/wiki/Academy_Award
"Academy Award"), and the pastiche of styles and dreams that pervades
[Tinseltown](/wiki/Tinseltown "Tinseltown")."[135]

## Nomination
process[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Nomination process")]

[![Director James Cameron squats by his new star, left hand propping up his
plaque](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/JamesCameronStarDec09.jpg/170px-
JamesCameronStarDec09.jpg)](/wiki/File:JamesCameronStarDec09.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:JamesCameronStarDec09.jpg "Enlarge")

Director [James Cameron](/wiki/James_Cameron "James Cameron") unveiling his
star, 2009

Each year an average of 200 nominations are submitted to the Hollywood Chamber
of Commerce Walk of Fame selection committee. Anyone, including fans, can
nominate anyone active in the field of entertainment as long as the nominee or
his or her management approves the nomination (a letter of agreement from the
nominated celebrity or representative must accompany the application).
Nominees must have a minimum of five years' experience in the category for
which they are nominated and a history of "charitable contributions."[74]
Posthumous nominees must have been deceased at least five years. At a meeting
each June, the committee selects approximately 20 to 24 celebrities to receive
stars on the Walk of Fame. One posthumous award is given each year as well.
The nominations of those not selected are rolled over to the following year
for reconsideration; those not selected two years in a row are dropped, and
must be renominated to receive further consideration. Living recipients must
agree to personally attend a presentation ceremony within two years of
selection. If the ceremony is not scheduled within two years, a new
application must be submitted. A relative of deceased recipients must attend
posthumous presentations. Presentation ceremonies are open to the public.[4]

A fee of $40,000 (as of
2018[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit)),[37]
payable at time of selection, is collected to pay for the creation and
installation of the star, as well as general maintenance of the Walk of Fame.
The fee is usually paid by the nominating organization, which may be a fan
club, or a film studio, record company, broadcaster, or other sponsor involved
with the prospective honoree.[21][136] The [Starz](/wiki/Starz_\(TV_channel\)
"Starz \(TV channel\)") cable network, for example, paid for [Dennis
Hopper](/wiki/Dennis_Hopper "Dennis Hopper")'s star as part of the promotion
for its series _Crash_. The star was unveiled in March 2010 shortly before
Hopper's death.[21][137]

[![Actor Matt Damon's star under construction, showing the brass star-shaped
rim, exposed wire grid foundation, brass letters attached to two horizontal
brackets, and the Motion Picture emblem, prior to pouring of pink
terrazzo](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Matt_Damon_Star_Under_Construction.jpg/220px-
Matt_Damon_Star_Under_Construction.jpg)](/wiki/File:Matt_Damon_Star_Under_Construction.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Matt_Damon_Star_Under_Construction.jpg "Enlarge")

Actor [Matt Damon](/wiki/Matt_Damon "Matt Damon")'s star under construction,
August 2007

Numerous major entertainment figures and legendary show business acts are not
included on the Walk of Fame for a variety of reasons. Some, such as [Julia
Roberts](/wiki/Julia_Roberts "Julia Roberts")[25][138] and [Clint
Eastwood](/wiki/Clint_Eastwood "Clint Eastwood"),[138] have declined to
participate; nominations cannot proceed without the nominee's consent. Others,
such as [George Clooney](/wiki/George_Clooney "George Clooney") and [John
Denver](/wiki/John_Denver "John Denver"),[139] were nominated, but would not
agree to the mandatory personal appearance at the unveiling ceremony; however,
Denver received a posthumous star in late 2014.[140] Others have simply never
been nominated, or do not have a nominator willing or able to pay the
selection fee, or have less than the required five years' minimum involvement
in their designated field. Probability also plays a role as only about 10% of
nominees are selected each year.

Traditionally, the identities of selection committee members, other than its
chairman, have not been made public in order to minimize conflicts of interest
and to discourage lobbying by celebrities and their representatives (a
significant problem during the original selections in the late 1950s).
However, in 1999, in response to intensifying charges of secrecy in the
selection process, the chamber disclosed the members' names: Johnny Grant, the
longtime chair and representative of the television category; [Earl
Lestz](/wiki/Earl_Lestz "Earl Lestz"), president of [Paramount Studio
Group](/wiki/Paramount_Pictures "Paramount Pictures") (motion pictures); Stan
Spero, retired manager with broadcast stations [KMPC](/wiki/KMPC "KMPC") and
[KABC](/wiki/KABC_\(AM\) "KABC \(AM\)") (radio); Kate Nelson, owner of the
[Palace Theatre](/wiki/Avalon_Hollywood "Avalon Hollywood") (live
performance); and Mary Lou Dudas, vice president of [A&M
Records](/wiki/A%26M_Records "A&M Records") (recording industry).[141] Since
that 1999 announcement the chamber has revealed only that Lestz (who received
his own star in 2004) became chairman after Grant died in 2008. Their current
official position is that "each of the five categories is represented by
someone with expertise in that field."[4]

In 2010, Lestz was replaced as chairman by John Pavlik, former Director of
Communications for the [Academy of Motion Picture Arts and
Sciences](/wiki/Academy_of_Motion_Picture_Arts_and_Sciences "Academy of Motion
Picture Arts and Sciences").[142] While no public announcement was made to
that effect, he was identified as chairman in the chamber's press release
announcing the 2011 star recipients.[143] The current chair, according to the
chamber's 2016 selection announcement, is film producer Maureen Schultz.[144]

##
Homage[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Homage")]

[![Recording artist Michael Jackson's star, surrounded by flowers, candles,
and cards, as observed about two weeks after his death in
2009](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Michael_Jackson_Star.JPG/220px-
Michael_Jackson_Star.JPG)](/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_Star.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Michael_Jackson_Star.JPG "Enlarge")

Michael Jackson's star, about two weeks after his death in 2009

Some fans show respect for star recipients both living and dead by laying
flowers or other symbolic tributes at their stars.[145] Others show their
support in other ways; the star awarded to [Julio
Iglesias](/wiki/Julio_Iglesias "Julio Iglesias"), for example, is kept in
"pristine condition [by] a devoted band of elderly women [who] scrub and
polish it once a month".[145]

The Hollywood Chamber of Commerce has adopted the tradition of placing flower
wreaths at the stars of newly deceased awardees; for example [Bette
Davis](/wiki/Bette_Davis "Bette Davis") in 1989,[146] [Katharine
Hepburn](/wiki/Katharine_Hepburn "Katharine Hepburn") in 2003, and [Jackie
Cooper](/wiki/Jackie_Cooper "Jackie Cooper") in 2011.[147] The stars of other
deceased celebrities, such as [Michael Jackson](/wiki/Michael_Jackson "Michael
Jackson"), [Elizabeth Taylor](/wiki/Elizabeth_Taylor "Elizabeth Taylor"),[148]
[Richard Pryor](/wiki/Richard_Pryor "Richard Pryor"),[149] [Ricardo
Montalbán](/wiki/Ricardo_Montalb%C3%A1n "Ricardo Montalbán"), [James
Doohan](/wiki/James_Doohan "James Doohan"), [Frank
Sinatra](/wiki/Frank_Sinatra "Frank Sinatra"),[150][151] [Robin
Williams](/wiki/Robin_Williams "Robin Williams"),[152] [Joan
Rivers](/wiki/Joan_Rivers "Joan Rivers"), [George
Harrison](/wiki/George_Harrison "George Harrison")[153], and [Aretha
Franklin](/wiki/Aretha_Franklin "Aretha Franklin") have become impromptu
memorial and vigil sites as well, and some continue to receive anniversary
remembrances.
